content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Playing with bases is really interesting, quite simple if you already know how to play with them

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interresting challenge! Lets play with bases!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good simple challenge.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Nice challenge but, I think your statement could be improved. 

Current statement:
"You have two integers b and n. Convert <DECIMAL> n in base b, reverse the obtained <NUMBER> and <PRINT> the result in base 10."

<DECIMAL> : n is not a decimal, you could omit this qualificative 
<NUMBER> : the result of the conversion might not be an actual number depending on the base
<PRINT> : 'output' would be more generic to all programming languages and, you could also specify that the output is x.

Suggestion : 
"You have two integers b and n. Convert n to base b, reverse the obtained value then output the result x in base 10."
This is way too hard to guess for reverse. I like the rest of the challenge though.

You must give a limit to the base size, 36 would be good because it would be :
"0123456789abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"
Otherwise the puzzle is too hard depending on the language.
PS : I know you don't necessarily need to convert to an actual base, you could make a table of numbers but I think it denatures the puzzle.

Input section
* Please split the input description into two lines and add line numbers. You may refer to the example here for the presentation:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement#guidelines

Thanks.

Hi ! I do not agree with that, base can be over 36, as you say in your PS, we don't need letters to represent value of intermediate number, only values from 0 to b-1. All languages can easily deal with that. See my solution. It's not very easy but I have played harder clashes than this one. Perhaps put the puzzle in shortest code rather reverse mode.

Perhaps, I could have put two first examples in base 10 to clearly show the reversion. 
So I suggest shortest mode.
Thx, I have modified the statement.
I didn't see that this was made for reverse mode. It is absolutely not suited for reverse. It would be nearly impossible to find.

This puzzle could really be interesting in shortest since there is a very simple solution but I insist that the base should be limited to 36 to give a chance for beginners to find a solution and multiply the ways of solving it. The winners would still be the ones who do it as you do.
Ok I limit but I think the limitation is a poisoned gift !
